titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Still confined to the house by the badness of the weather, and reading Camilla, and the power of Love, in tales by the German Lafontaine.— Mrs: A.’s illness delays but to distress the more.

2. Walked this forenoon a little among the shops at the fair this forenoon— Went in the evening to the play, where I saw, the two preceptors, a Comedy translated from the french by Madame Kotzebue, and Wallenstein’s camp, by Schiller; a sort of prologue written in doggrel rhyme, to the two historical plays, of Wallensteins life and death— This prologue is not permitted to be exhibited at Berlin, where I saw the other two pieces.

3. Walked round the fair again before dinner— Letters from Berlin and to Mrs: A. from America— The last however a year old— Finished reading Miss Burney’s Camilla; and took at the circulating library Lesage’s Bachelier de Salamanque.
4. Wrote a short letter to the Secretary of State.— Walk before dinner— The streets scarcely passable. Visit in the afternoon from Dr: Kapp.
5. Walk’d round the town before dinner.— Visit this afternoon from Mr: Frege— My cough becomes again very troublesome. It is the worst I ever had.

6. At Bookseller’s shops— Purchased Florian’s translation of Don Quixote, and Roscoe’s life of Lorenzo de Medici. Read part of the first volume of the Don Quixote— It is by far the best I have read, but takes too great liberties with the original.

7. Weather warm— Walk before and after dinner— Sent an excuse to Mr: Frege for not dining with him, owing to my cough— His nephew called in the evening and paid me a visit— He has been five or six years in America— Came from Philadelphia about three months ago, and intends to return and settle there, the next Spring.

8. Mr: J. R. Murray, who was at Berlin last winter, called to see me this morning. He has been travelling ever since I last saw him, and intends going from this place to Paris— Was confined again this day to the house, my cough being very troublesome.

9. Walk’d about an hour this afternoon— Find myself very weak— Mr: Murray called and pass’d an hour with us this evening.— I lead more than ever a life of fainéantise— Mrs: A— is never well, a whole day through— But the misfortune lingers this time, to make itself more keenly felt.
10. Walk’d half an hour in the morning; and as much in the afternoon.— Finish’d reading Lesage’s history of Guzman d’Alfarache. Mrs: A. very unwell at night.

11. Went to look at a collection of pictures which are to be sold next week— Some of them are very fine. Mr: Murray called to take leave of us— He goes to-morrow morning, for Frankfort on the Mayn. Whitcomb went away this evening for Berlin— Took from the circulating library two volumes of Amadis des Gaules.— Weather dull, rainy and cold.
12. My cough appears again to be getting better— Took a walk this afternoon round the walls of the town— Reading Amadis des Gaules, which I find very tedious.

13. Walking round the town this afternoon I met Mr: Sloper— He arrived last evening from Berlin, and says the roads are very bad— He thinks of returning to England soon— Weather very cold— I am still unable to write but very little.
14. Weather so bad, I was obliged to confine myself to the house all day.— Began to read Roscoe’s life of Lorenzo de Medici.— No letters from Berlin; which was something of a disappointment.

15. Mrs: A— very unwell the whole day with a severe head ache— Took a short walk in the forenoon, but was driven home by the rain— Walk’d round the town in the afternoon. Saw in the Leipzig Gazette an account of a Treaty, having been signed the 1st: of this month, between France, and the U.S.

16. Mrs: A— went out in a chair, but is yet very weak.— In the afternoon I was at the circulating library; and read the English papers to the 7th:— Finished reading the adventures of Amadis, and his son Esplandian, which I found great difficulty in getting through— Began Marivaux’s Vie de Marianne. Received this day the letter from Berlin which should have come the day before yesterday.
17. The weather at length so cold we were obliged to have a fire— Took a walk round the town before dinner.— My disorder has not yet entirely left me.
18. The fair finishes this day.— Was unable to walk out, having hurt my foot. Received letters from Berlin, with one from Genl: Beurnonville, and one from Mr: Murray— Answered the General’s letter.
19. Extremely unwell the whole day, with a new complaint— Obliged to keep my bed the greatest part of the day. But my cough is gone, and I hope this will prove serviceable to me.

20. My illness which appeared better in the morning, soon return’d and continued the whole day. Took a short ride out of town with Mrs: A. before dinner.— Mr: Sloper spent most of the evening with us.

21. Continued ill, all night and the greater part of this day— Towards evening my complaint seems moderating. Whitcomb arrived in the evening; having left the carriage and horses for which I sent him to Berlin, with our coachman, at Wittenberg.— One of the horses very ill— Mrs: A.’s health too, at the time when we might have hoped the danger past, is more threatening than it has been yet.
22. Preparing this day for our departure; upon which we have determined, for to-morrow morning. Called this afternoon upon Mr: Frege, and took leave of him.

23. At 9 this morning we left Leipzig, and came one stage of four miles to Düben, where we arrived between two and three o’clock in the afternoon. Owing to Mrs: A’s weak state of health we came only a single stage— The roads are much better however than I had expected.

24. At eight this morning we left Düben, and arrived at Wittenberg, after a stage of four miles, at about 1 in the afternoon— Here we found our coachman, with the horses— One of them still so sick that he could not proceed with us— Mrs: A. was so well that she preferr’d going another stage of four miles, and at 9 in the evening, we reach’d Treuenbriezen.

25. Between 6 and 7. this morning we proceeded upon our journey—to Beliz two miles, and to Potsdam the same distance. But the roads are through such deep sands that we did not reach Potsdam untill nearly 5 o’clock in the afternoon. We waited only to change horses, and got home at Berlin just at ten in the evening.

26. Walking under the lime-trees, I met, Mr: Engeström and General O’Farrill, Mr: Garlike, and Mr: Navarro. Doctor Brown called to see us— We pass’d the evening at his house. Mr: Perponcher there part of the time.
27. Paid a visit to Lord Carysfort, to whom Mr: Garlike introduced me. Went afterwards to Mr: Schickler’s compting house.— Doctor Brown called upon me. Spent the evening at home.
28. Baron Posch called this afternoon and paid us a visit.— I took a long walk in the park. Find myself not yet wholly recovered from my illness. Evening again at home.

29. Mrs: Brown, her daughters, and the Doctor spent the evening with us; play’d chess with him— Mrs: St: George likewise paid a visit to Mrs: A.— Our carriage from Wittenberg came home this night; but without the horses.
30. Lord Carysfort called to return my visit.— Spent the evening and supped at Mr: Cohen’s— Found him restored in health and looks. Play’d chess with him— Met Mr: Dampmartin there.

31. Mrs: A. called on Madame de Sartoris, who is in a very ill state of health— Going to the South of France. I pass’d the evening at the Minister Heinitz’s— Play’d Casino, with ladies and a gentleman whom I did not know— Mrs: A. pass’d the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s.
Day. Not yet regularly settled.
